title: M&A Strategy with Joel Sherlock - 7 Cellars
content:
# M&A Strategy with Joel Sherlock - 7 Cellars

**Date:** 2025-12-07  
**Location:** [Not specified]  
**Duration:** 34m 31s  
**Participants:** Joel Sherlock, Consultants  
**Source:** [Plaud Recording](https://web.plaud.ai/s/pub_c61cfbdc-9f6f-47b3-8cf4-8d377f461198::Gfdg-SkqJ-NMSigRFTzDzppq1NlToGKqDgsSdcS2B_VV1IiG-LcdsFi9h69-ZYOigdR4HnGWSef4m9QC)

---

## Acquisition and Partnership Strategy for Cayman Wine Business

### Target Operator Profile
- **"Rob/Roberto":** mid-60s, hospitality background (former F&B director, tableside flambés), customer-service oriented; dislikes back-office; passion project mindset
- Wife runs successful commercial cleaning business (160 employees), providing household security

### Role Design and Operating Model
- Rob positioned as GM and white-glove customer service lead
- Back office, inventory, financing, billing, website, logistics fully centralized by buyer group
- Keep Rob in "zone of genius" — service and relationships

### Salary and Compensation
- **Base salary recommendation:** $100,000
- **Equity:** initial 10% at closing + additional 10% vested on performance (sales growth, profitability, KPIs)
- Equity valuation context: current business ~$300k → 10% = ~$30k; long-term target $10–$20M enterprise value

### Debt and Risk Removal
- Identify personal debts funding inventory (e.g., $80k LOC, $60k credit card)
- Structure repayment from inventory liquidation within first 6 months

### Purchase Price Structure
- Shareholder loan/earn-out: pay from free cash flow (e.g., $100k/year for 3 years = $300k)
- Rationale: business likely wouldn't fetch $300k if listed today; earn-out preserves capital for website, inventory, salary

### Strategic Rationale
- "Fast-forward" 2–3 years of execution and learning curve
- Execution risk: wrong GM or reputation damage could force rebrand/restart

### Negotiation Posture
- Transparent and firm: buyer group entering Cayman wine regardless; well funded; licenses secured
- Friendly but clear "join us or compete" framing
- Get Rob's valuation number early to anchor expectations

### Growth Targets
| Scenario | Year 1 | Year 2 | Year 3 |
|----------|--------|--------|--------|
| Without Rob | ~$150k | ~$400k | ~$1M |
| With Rob | ~$1M | — | — |

Net positive even paying $300k if relationships accelerate time-to-profit.

---

## Case Study: ClearSolve Deal Mechanics

- Counterparty "Dan" had ethanol licenses and beverage company
- Buyer purchased 50% by matching invested capital + shared LOC secured by all shares
- Minimal draw (~$50k); within a year, sales supported new LOC; buyer recovered cash + $3M dividend in ~18 months
- **Lessons:** Match capital, secure LOC, leverage early traction to refinance; pay from business cash flow

---

## Go-To-Market and Brand Expansion

### Olive Oil Brand
- High-end Italian olive oil with strong production but weak branding
- Plan: buy bulk, redesign packaging, manage brand; aligns with wine portfolio

### Tuscany Property
- Considering vineyard acquisition with olive oil and wine production
- White-label amendments with DOCG producers to accelerate market entry
- Distribution: Puerto Rico (restaurant network), Cayman (Seven Cellars), US (Texas), plus additional

### Product Strategy
- Focus on approachable Italian reds (Super Tuscans) for non-collectors
- Obscure Italian reds: 80% of quality at 20% of price vs top-tier
- Burgundy positioning for connoisseurs

---

## Cayman Market Data

- Top restaurants: ~250–350 cases/month across all SKUs
- Baseline: 2 cases/month per account = 24 cases/year per SKU
- Seven Cellars status: operational (bank accounts, apparel, cards, emails, licenses, 7cellars.ky)

---

## Risk Management

| Risk | Mitigation |
|------|------------|
| Misfit GM / brand damage | Performance vesting, back-office controls |
| Overvaluation / blue-sky projections | Early anchor from Rob, structured earn-out |
| License timing | Already secured |

---

## Action Items

- [ ] Confirm Rob's desired base salary; finalize $100k offer
- [ ] Define GM role scope; document back-office split
- [ ] Request full financials: revenue, margins, inventory, liabilities, cash flow
- [ ] Quantify Rob's personal debt on inventory; draft assumption/retirement plan (6 months)
- [ ] Obtain Rob's valuation number; set early anchor
- [ ] Structure equity: 10% at closing + 10% performance vesting with KPIs
- [ ] Draft purchase terms: shareholder loan/earn-out from free cash flow
- [ ] Build 3-year revenue scenarios (with/without Rob) to validate ROI
- [ ] Communicate market entry intent with preference to partner
- [ ] Rebuild website/digital presence for Seven Cellars
- [ ] Develop SKU strategy: Burgundy, Italian reds, Super Tuscans; map target accounts
- [ ] Establish working LOC with Kyle; set interest terms (~10%)
- [ ] Begin olive oil brand development
- [ ] Coordinate Tuscany sourcing trips; appoint Italian tasting/rep role
- [ ] Map distribution beyond Cayman: Puerto Rico, Texas, US relationships
- [ ] Prepare negotiation script: transparency, partnership preference, market entry inevitability
- [ ] Schedule in-person meeting (Rob's suggested New Year's B.C. trip)

title: Roberto Vino Veritas - 7 Cellars (1st Visit)
content:
# Roberto Vino Veritas - 7 Cellars (1st Visit)

**Date:** 2025-12-06  
**Location:** Cayman Islands  
**Duration:** 1h 48m 48s  
**Participants:** Roberto (Vino Veritas), Consultants  
**Source:** [Plaud Recording](https://web.plaud.ai/s/pub_3310c670-d7ba-41f1-8ac4-c80f083ca749::5J3jVOJZ_5H-QG0be8eV40HptQfPUdtOd_EauESidWN8f7_CWlbE-HmZqO-QaetbPmb9m1SKk_wMKSAC)

---

## Executive Summary

The Cayman Islands wine market presents a clear opportunity for a service-led, quality-focused distributor to capture share from incumbent players through superior customer experience, curated portfolios, and selective exclusivity. While licensing and capital intensity pose constraints, the combination of Roberto's procurement relationships and local rapport with an operationally strong, well-capitalized partner can scale a differentiated model targeting high-end restaurants, ultra-high-net-worth (UHNW) clients, and boutique retail.

## Market Structure and Licensing

- Cayman restaurant licenses include import rights, enabling direct wine imports; however, many venues reverted to distributors due to high warehouse costs, slow inventory turnover, and cash flow constraints
- Government considering raising wine/spirits license fees from ~CI$4.5–4.8k to ~CI$25k, pressuring smaller operators

## Current Market Conditions and Demand

- Unusually weak wine sales in Sept–Oct; more restaurants closed entire September and early October
- August "so-so"; November weaker than last year
- Tourism demand closely tied to US visitor trends
- Cayman continues to attract new wealth (including crypto); higher-end concepts expanding, some hiring sommeliers

## Competitive Landscape and Pricing

- Large distributors (CDG, Jacques Scott) rely on aggressive discounting to manage inventory (e.g., Prosecco retail at CI$12.99)
- Jacques Scott requires accounts to purchase ~75% of products to access certain wine-by-the-glass offerings
- Widely reported service deficiencies create gap for "white glove," rapid-response model
- Notable talent: Adam at Jacques Scott (high service, potential recruitment target)

### Market Context and Inventory Dynamics
- CDG's clearance pricing reflects high overhead and need to make room after slow Aug–Nov
- DART oversight and margin pressures may lead to conservative ordering next year, opening windows for agile competitors

## Regulatory and Compliance

- Government exploring PR fee increases and potential cancellations for problematic non-citizens
- Team advantages: strong local ties (Kyle married a Caymanian), commitment to ethical operations

## Roberto's Business Model and Positioning

- Current operation intentionally lean and hobby-like due to capacity/capital limits; emphasizes quality and selective exclusivity
- Protects venue differentiation (e.g., supply Luca but avoid selling same SKUs next door; allow limited radius expansion)
- Demonstrated high-touch service: rapid fulfillment (e.g., 10 cases of Prosecco delivered next morning for Grand Old House)
- Strategy: seed key openings (e.g., 1GT in Feb; Grand in July) with limited, strong SKUs; scale breadth later

## Product Strategy and Unit Economics (Prosecco Example)

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Net purchase price | ~€2.50/bottle after discounts |
| Logistics | ~CI$1.30/bottle |
| Duty | ~CI$5.80/bottle |
| Landed cost | ~CI$9/bottle |
| Entry wholesale | CI$13/bottle (~CI$4 margin) |
| Post-adoption wholesale | CI$18–19 |
| Post-adoption retail | CI$26–28 (Private Cuvée) |

## Watermark Opportunity (UHNW Focus)

- Weekly tastings/pairings; individual wine lockers for 50 units; many billionaire owners with large cellars
- Service expectation: white-glove experience; zero-markup bar pricing for owners; demand for niche SKUs (e.g., Taittinger non-alcoholic sparkling)
- Implementation: secure SKUs via direct rep relationships (Bichot/Taittinger), inventory tech (automated rack scanning), monthly invoicing, sommelier-driven replenishment
- Roberto cannot deliver alone at this scale; partnership committed not to bypass him

## Capacity, Constraints, and Infrastructure

- Current capacity: two containers/year due to capital limits; significant inventory held
- Website/digital presence is critical weakness; requires overhaul
- Available assets: existing corporate entity and licenses; 5,000 sq ft climate-controlled storage (Kyle's facility)
- Logistics: pallets from Europe ~28–30 days via Tropical; small-case DHL ~5–10 days (higher cost)

## Pricing, Margins, and Volumes

- Champagne margin ~30% to keep quality accessible
- Wholesale multipliers: 1.875x–2.10x; retail add ~30%; rare vintages 3–4x
- At least two 40-foot containers per shipment capacity
- Consider lowered markups (e.g., 1.60x) to expand placements, contingent on supply and working capital

## Investment and Partnership Options

### Partnership Pathways:
1. **Acquisition:** Integrated Vino acquires Vino Veritas
2. **Investor-partnership:** Integrated Vino invests for equity; Roberto retains stake
- Roberto favors "Coppola" model with retained ownership and pride

### Wine Fund Concept:
- Minimum investment ~US$500k, 5-year horizon, select appreciating vintages
- Storage in secure European vaults; partner with trading firms

## Retail and Experience Concepts

- Boutique retail in Walker's Road/Red Bay corridors with premium accessories (e.g., Riedel)
- **"Cantina" concept:** crystal carafe tastings, rotating food items, family-oriented (inspired by Chateau Elan)
- **Vino tourism:** winery experiences (barrel tastings, winemaker sessions, cooking classes) via European connections

## Facilities, Costs, and Logistics

- Current facility ~2,000 sq ft; rent ~CI$4,935/month; utilities ~CI$1,800/month (24/7 AC at 64°F)
- Kyle's buildings provide scalable storage at fair market terms
- Tropical shipping: Wednesday/Sunday arrivals; Thursday clearance

## Risks and Sensitivities

- License fee hikes could compress margins
- Competitive discounting requires smart SKU management
- Working capital and inventory turnover critical for sustained low markups

---

## Action Plan

### Licensing and Compliance
- Validate timing/impact of license fee changes; update pro forma economics
- Map PR/status regulatory shifts; document compliance plan

### Market and Pricing
- Audit competitor pricing/SKUs across top venues
- Implement pricing transition: wholesale CI$13 → CI$18–19; retail CI$26–28
- Define restaurant markup policy (e.g., 1.60x) contingent on supply cadence

### Portfolio and Sourcing
- Secure Taittinger non-alcoholic sparkling via Bichot/Taittinger rep
- Develop initial portfolio of small, high-quality domaines (10–20 case allocations)
- Request Roberto's shortlist of rare vintages and niche champagnes

### Operations and Infrastructure
- Full inventory count and independent valuation; quantify capital needs
- Assess storage capacity (Kyle's facility vs current)
- Replace website vendor; launch 90-day digital overhaul
- Hire logistics support; implement inventory/CRM/accounting systems

### Key Accounts and Pilots
- Pilot white-glove service with Grand Old House, Luca; define emergency delivery SLAs
- Finalize Prosecco placements for 1GT (Feb) and Grand (July)
- Engage Watermark (Sean) with curated list, tech demo, sommelier recommendations

### Talent
- Explore recruitment of Adam; establish sommelier pipeline via European schools
- Consider consulting with Erin and a Master Sommelier

### Partnership Structure
- Prepare financial models for acquisition vs investor-partnership
- Structure roles, capital, inventory strategy, exclusivity policy

### Retail and Experiences
- Design/pilot "cantina" concept; secure retail locations
- Plan wine tourism programs (3–4 trips/year)

title: Chad @ Craft Food & Beverage Co. - 7 Cellars
content:
# Chad @ Craft Food & Beverage Co. - 7 Cellars

**Date:** 2025-12-04
**Attendees:** Darryl Hicks, Chad (Craft F&B Owner), Erin (Sommelier), Kyle
**Location:** Cayman Islands
**Duration:** 55m 26s
**Source:** Plaud

## Summary
This consultation focused on establishing a boutique wine distribution business in the Cayman Islands to address gaps left by existing large distributors. Chad represents a significant restaurant group managing approximately **10 restaurants**. The discussion highlights dissatisfaction with the current market monopoly, specifically the lack of wine variety, poor customer service, and restrictive purchasing requirements. The desired outcome is a white-glove partnership where 7 Cellars provides exclusive wine portfolios, reliable delivery, and staff training (sommelier support) to differentiate client venues from competitors.

## Background
The meeting takes place between the 7 Cellars team (representing a new distribution venture with partners Kyle and Dwayne) and a stakeholder in a large local restaurant group. Key context includes limitations of current dominant distributors (Jacques Scott, Tortuga), the high-end needs of the Watermark project (50 units with wine lockers), and the plan to secure **5,000 square feet** of warehousing (starting at **2,500**).

## Pain Points

### 1. Lack of Product Differentiation and Market Saturation
**Problem:** Wine lists across the island are nearly identical due to limited distributor options, making it difficult to offer a unique dining experience.
**Impact:** Restaurants cannot differentiate; customers see the same brands everywhere, reducing perceived value.
**Quote:** "Every single one of these places along the beach has Rombauer and Duckhorn and that's it."

### 2. Poor Distributor Service and Forced Bundling
**Problem:** Existing distributors leverage their monopoly to force unfavorable terms and refuse to source specific products.
**Impact:** Cannot get desired wines without accepting unwanted inventory.
**Quote:** "If you take that, you have to take two pieces of my shitty rosé at the same time."

### 3. Staff Knowledge and Training Gaps
**Problem:** Lack of qualified sommeliers and general wine knowledge among floor staff, hindering effective selling of premium wines.
**Impact:** Without proper training, customers may not understand why a $105 bottle is better than a recognizable brand.
**Solution Proposed:** "Fractional sommelier" model to address this.

## Expectations

### 1. White-Glove Service and Reliability
- High-touch service model focused on saying "yes" to requests
- Weekly deliveries
- Responsive customer service representatives
- Timeline: Watermark about a year away; distribution business starting "pretty soon"

### 2. Exclusive and Curated Product Portfolio
- Wine list unique and not available at local liquor stores
- Including back vintages (10, 15, 20 years old)
- Leveraging connections to wineries in Burgundy and Canada
- Strong margins on exclusive bottles ($30-$50 cost basis)

### 3. Support for Watermark Private Owners
- High-end consultation and stocking services for 50 units with private wine lockers
- Wine-themed events and tastings
- Cellar build consultations

## Key Points
- Chad's group manages approximately 10 restaurants on island
- Current pricing: 10% discount off retail for licensees
- Target margins on bottles: $30-$50 depending on cost
- Chad validates market opportunity: "Way more so now than 10 years ago"
- Canadian migration creating new high-net-worth clientele
- Adam from Jacques Scott is current rep - excellent customer service
- Interest in "fractional sommelier" model for staff training
- Future vodka brand (Caymanian premium vodka) planned for 3 years out

## Action Items
- [ ] 7 Cellars to find/refer a candidate for Sommelier/Executive Chef position for Chad
- [ ] Note hiring practices/resources for hospitality recruitment
- [ ] Stay in touch regarding distribution business launch timeline
- [ ] Connect with Dale's contact regarding three restaurants
- [ ] Consider "Curated Exclusive Collections" with contractual exclusivity

## AI Suggestions
1. **Curated "Exclusive" Collections:** Create tiered portfolio where specific rare vintages are contractually exclusive to restaurant group
2. **Fractional Sommelier Program:** Bundle distribution with monthly training package
3. **Menu Engineering Consultation:** Design wine pairings using unique SKUs to demonstrate margin improvements
4. **VIP Tasting Events:** Host exclusive tastings for Watermark owners

## Other Information
- **Future Vodka Brand:** Plan to launch high-end Caymanian vodka in ~3 years
- **Consultant Background:** Tech business using AI for fraud analysis on Visa/Mastercard rails
- **Market Context:** "Canadian mafia" in Cayman; political/tax situations driving wealthy Canadians to move to island
- **Trade Issues:** Tariff war caused $14 million worth of US inventory pulled from shelves in Nova Scotia

## Full Transcript

**00:00:00 - Chad:** He spoke to my partner, but I wasn't present at that point whenever I was in that, so you can maybe give me a rundown of what you're doing.

**00:00:00 - Darryl:** Yeah, so we're looking to, well, we've already started down the road with more of a boutique distribution. We want to fill gaps where more nimble, the smaller, the... We've got up to 5,000 square feet at the moment. We're starting off at 25, but we can just not renew at least.

**00:02:16 - Darryl:** I kept coming down and just noticed that there was, it was tough to get some of the wines that I really enjoy back up in Canada. It just seems like there's a lot of gaps here and when we were talking to Kyle, we're all like serial entrepreneurs, and Kyle exited out of Ironshore, and he's got a bunch of rental units here, and I feel like he's just kind of getting a little bit bored.

**00:03:03 - Darryl:** So we're all hanging out together this summer, and I've wanted to have a business down here for obvious reasons as a Canadian for a while. I'm super passionate about wine, have a ton of contacts, close personal friends who are like owners of wineries in Burgundy, and some of the best wineries in Canada.

**00:03:34 - Darryl:** There'd probably be an opportunity to do something white glove differentiated. Aaron's like a killer sommelier and so we said what if we came down instead of working with some of the restaurants to say we could actually help you build a really really great wine list.

**00:06:04 - Darryl:** What's your take on that? Do you think that there's a gap there in the market for us to fill?

**00:06:04 - Chad:** Way more so now than there was 10 years ago. Really? Absolutely.

**00:12:02 - Darryl:** We have a vision for like, say, three years from now, where we actually want to have our own brand, like a Caymanian super high end luxury vodka, maybe some RTDs to go along with it. But the way to start now is by doing the wine business, the wine import.

**00:12:33 - Darryl:** We've heard stories from other people that said, well, I asked for this particular SKU from Jacques Scott, and they're like, I'm not going to import that for you. Or he's like, well, that's a really exclusive SKU. If you take that, you have to take two pieces of my shitty rosé at the same time.

**00:19:00 - Darryl:** Every single one of these places along the beach has Rombauer and Duckhorn and that's it and it's like I'm like really, again.

**00:26:20 - Darryl:** So that's great validation. Appreciate that. I think what we're hoping to do is partner with the Psalms and say, hey, what do you want? We can source back vintages. Stuff like 10 years old, 15 years old on a lot of the wine lists around here.

**00:28:03 - Darryl:** And do what you say you're going to do, and do it on time, right? Yeah, actually deliver. So that's what we plan to do. We want to be like that niche player here who builds a reputation on being like, we're the guys who deliver.

**00:43:15 - Darryl:** Do you think there'd be a market for that? Like if you had something, okay, maybe not in the restaurants, but like Kyle is absolutely convinced that there is a hole in the market for like something that Caymanians can be really proud of that's from here. And he thinks it should be a really good premium vodka.

**00:51:38 - Chad:** Cool. Well, man, I really appreciate the help. Yeah, stay in touch and let me know when you're getting things rolling. If you have questions, reach out to me.

**00:52:11 - Darryl:** We've got the relationships, we've got the licenses, we've got the warehouse space. We're going to get started here pretty soon, so we'd love to keep in touch with you.

**00:53:26 - Erin:** Having someone who is focused on the wine, that's why you can't do everything. So they focus on putting that together, and they do the staff training, the staff education.

**00:53:48 - Darryl:** In tech, we have this expression, time to first value. This will be my time to first value for you. I'm going to find you a sommelier.

- [ ] Consultant to find/refer a candidate for the Sommelier/Executive Chef position
- [ ] Consultant to note hiring practices/resources
- [ ] Client and consultant to stay in touch regarding distribution business launch timeline
- [ ] Client to connect with Dale's contact regarding the three restaurants

## AI Suggestions

Biggest pain point identified: **Lack of Product Differentiation and Market Saturation**

1. **Curated "Exclusive" Collections:** Create tiered portfolio with contractually exclusive rare vintages/boutique labels for this restaurant group
2. **Fractional Sommelier Program:** Monthly "Sommelier-for-a-Day" training package bundled with distribution
3. **Menu Engineering Consultation:** Design wine pairings using unique SKUs to increase margin and guest satisfaction
4. **VIP Tasting Events:** Leverage Watermark connection for exclusive tasting events creating pull-demand

title: Richard - Kimpton - 7 Cellars
content:
# Richard - Kimpton - 7 Cellars

**Date:** 2025-12-04  
**Location:** Kimpton Hotel  
**Duration:** 26m 14s  
**Participants:** Richard (Restaurant Manager, Kimpton), Consultants  
**Source:** [Plaud Recording](https://web.plaud.ai/s/pub_f43a433e-5bbc-40f1-8888-486d5eff1cbb::lGzuyNcOKeh1frUMa2SdzgT-OuJ_pzBSwKp9muQIeswlPLNMmr_A8LAce31kdY9G7__j4nbNHTCt7VsC)

---

## Overview

The consultation was with a restaurant manager at the Kimpton hotel, who has 18 years of experience in the food and beverage industry. The discussion centered on the launch of Seven Cellars Wine and Spirits in the Cayman Islands. The primary challenge identified is the lack of wine list diversity, with most restaurants offering identical selections from major distributors like CDG. The customer's restaurant is required to source 80-90% of its wine from CDG (owned by same parent company, Dart). Seven Cellars aims to address this gap with exclusive, custom-tailored wine selections and superior customer service.

## Background

- Restaurant manager at Kimpton hotel, 18 years experience in restaurant/bar industry
- Recently moved into management after bartending
- Establishment owned by Dart, which also owns major distributor CDG → 80-90% wine sourcing requirement from CDG
- Retains some freedom to purchase from other suppliers
- Broad network in local hospitality industry
- Has helped open restaurants and manage properties internationally (e.g., Penticton, Canada)

## Pain Points

### Wine List Homogenization
Most establishments feature identical wine selections from large, dominant distributors. Price rather than uniqueness is the main differentiator. The Kimpton strategically prices wines lower than the Ritz-Carlton. This limits ability to offer a "more special, more exclusive" experience. As observed: "it was like same here, same down the beach, same, you know."

### Distributor Customer Service
Feedback from industry peers indicates customer service from existing large distributors could be better. Superior service — being responsive, reliable, treating restaurants as valued customers — is a significant opportunity.

## Expectations

- **Exclusive wines** not currently available on the island — custom-tailored, "bespoke" wine lists matching restaurant's menu, clientele, and concept
- **Strong incentives** — perks like free case for every 10 ordered ("a case on 10"), branded items (buckets)
- **High-quality service** — responsive, reliable, relationship-building
- **Sourcing capability** — e.g., wines from Burgundy not currently imported to Cayman Islands; company that "just says yes" to requests

## Other Information

- Kimpton targets mature, family-oriented clientele; sister property INDIGRO caters to younger crowd (30s, early 40s)
- Kimpton pricing strategy: more competitive than Ritz-Carlton (e.g., $17 cost wine vs Ritz at $25)
- Seven Cellars also open to spirits distribution; long-term vision for premium Caymanian vodka and RTD products
- Restaurants like Luca, Grand Old House can obtain own import licenses and source directly
- Suggested venues for market research: Le Petit, Vine to Ocean, Aria

## To-Do List

- [ ] Send follow-up email to Richard with key questions for his F&B Director
- [ ] Prepare preliminary list of unique, exclusive wines (e.g., from Burgundy)
- [ ] Research Le Petit, Vine to Ocean, and Aria — analyze wine lists and business models
- [ ] Develop competitive incentive program ("1 free case per 10" model, branded value-adds)
- [ ] Schedule follow-up meeting with F&B Director

## AI Suggestions

Biggest pain point: **Wine list homogenization**

1. **Curate "Exclusivity Tiers":** Basic tier (unique but accessible) and premium "Signature" tier with restaurant-exclusive rights in specific areas
2. **Menu-Pairing Consultation:** Free consultation analyzing food menu to co-create bespoke wine list
3. **"Discovery" Program:** Rotating, limited-availability small-batch wines creating urgency and exclusivity
4. **Exclusive Tasting Events:** Invite F&B Directors to showcases of unavailable-elsewhere wines

title: Sean @ Watermark - 7 Cellars
content:
# Sean @ Watermark - 7 Cellars

**Date:** 2025-12-04  
**Location:** Ritz Lobby Bar  
**Duration:** 1h 0m 2s  
**Participants:** [Speaker 1], Darryl, [Speaker 3], [Speaker 4], [Speaker 5]  
**Source:** [Plaud Recording](https://web.plaud.ai/s/pub_cc2c9012-0fd3-4352-b256-0bece2d4d28e::Qt_dhqN_1mzICuQJR2gZtzL45eFqIC70Ku7RNkCVuuF3jvu4I2tmk6q6SYsHEjN7GxZsr6urEa8guBMC)

## Keywords
`Project Development`, `Luxury Amenities`, `Supply Chain Challenges`, `Wine Business`, `Cayman Islands`, `White-Glove Service`, `High-Net-Worth Clients`

---

## Summary

This meeting covered two main topics: the final stages of the Watermark luxury property development and a proposal for a new boutique wine and spirits business to serve high-net-worth clients on the island, including Watermark's residents.

The Watermark project is nearing completion, with furniture delivered and the spa being finished. The property boasts extensive five-star amenities, including a full bar, a large pool deck, private dining rooms, a cinema, and a 16,000 sq ft spa, aiming for a "mini resort" feel. The development, however, faced significant post-COVID supply chain disruptions, causing a year-long delay and budget overruns. Sourcing materials like plasterboard and specialized hurricane-rated windows proved challenging for the island-based construction. A major operational hurdle is the property's status as a Strata, which prevents it from obtaining import, liquor, or business licenses. This has made it difficult to source unique, curated food and beverage items, such as non-alcoholic champagne and golden caviar, as they are dependent on local distributors who may not carry these niche products.

In response to these sourcing challenges, a business opportunity was identified for a niche importer, wholesaler, and retailer of private wines and specialty spirits. The proposed business would focus on providing a "white-glove service" rather than competing on volume. This service would include a dedicated sommelier for client consultations, menu pairings, staff training, and building out private cellars for high-net-worth individuals. The service aims to source any SKU a client desires, creating unique collections and leveraging connections with small-production wineries.

[Speaker 4] from Watermark confirmed the need for such a service, noting their model provides food and wine to owners at cost and that their international, ultra-high-net-worth clients value privacy, discretion, and seamless service. While interested in the proposal, [Speaker 4]'s immediate priority for the next two quarters is the flawless move-in of 51 homeowners and ensuring the property is fully operational. It was agreed that they would reconnect to discuss the wine service collaboration after this initial phase is complete.

The meeting also included a casual discussion about a shared interest in Formula 1, with mentions of drivers like Lando Norris and experiences at the Montreal Grand Prix.

## Next Steps

- [Speaker 4] will focus on opening the Watermark property and managing the initial move-in and operational setup for the first two quarters of the next year.
- Darryl and [Speaker 4] will reconnect to discuss the white-glove wine service proposal after the Watermark property is fully operational and the initial resident move-in phase is complete.

## AI-Identified Issues

- **Licensing Deadlock:** The primary operational challenge for Watermark is its inability as a Strata to obtain import, liquor, and business licenses. This severely restricts sourcing unique products and creates dependency on local distributors. A clear strategy to navigate these restrictions is needed.
- **Sourcing Gap:** While the goal is to offer a unique beverage list, there is a gap in sourcing these products. The meeting did not establish a clear plan or partner to procure the desired high-end items not currently available on the island.
- **Vague Follow-up:** The agreement to reconnect after Watermark is "open and in there" lacks a specific timeline, leaving the next steps for the proposed wine business collaboration indefinite.
- **Undefined Business Model:** While the concept of a boutique wine service was well-received, concrete details regarding the business model (e.g., pricing for sommelier services, pilot project with Watermark) were not defined.

---

## Client Needs Analysis

**Customer:** Sean, Watermark

### Overview

The consultation is with Sean, who manages the new luxury five-star residency, the Watermark project. The property caters to ultra-high-net-worth individuals, with 51 residences and 48 billionaire owners. Sean's primary challenge is sourcing unique, high-quality products—specifically fine wines, non-alcoholic champagne, and caviar—to elevate the resident experience. Systemic issues, such as the Strata's lack of import, liquor, and business licenses, and the restrictive practices of large local distributors (e.g., forced bundling of unwanted products), prevent him from curating the exclusive food and beverage program he envisions. While interested in a "White Glove" wine service partnership that offers sourcing, cellar management, and staff training, Sean's immediate priority is the overwhelming operational task of opening the property and moving in the first 51 homeowners. He is therefore unavailable to engage in a new partnership until the property is fully operational, likely after the first two quarters of the next year.

### Background

The Watermark is a newly developed, high-end residential property nearing operational readiness. The team is expected to move in before Christmas to set up extensive amenities, including a 16,000 sq ft spa, a 12-room pool with 20 cabanas, two private dining rooms, and a 10-seater cinema. The property is unique as the developer, Fraser, is also an owner and the chairman of the executive committee, ensuring a long-term commitment to quality. The residents are exceptionally wealthy, with apartments averaging 15 million U.S. dollars and the final penthouse selling for 40 million.

The business model for amenities is unique: everything is provided to owners at cost, with no profit margin, as the stock is owned by the residents within the strata cost. The focus is entirely on providing an unparalleled, home-like experience through quality, exclusivity, and service. Each owner has a private, 56-bottle wine locker in a communal wine room. The property is also planning a "chef in residence" program, starting with a two-Michelin-star chef from London. Sean, who has a 40-year background in hospitality, is managing the launch, which involves complex logistics and handling initial building issues ("snagging").

### Pain Points

- **Sourcing & Supply Chain Limitations:** As a Strata, the property lacks the necessary import, liquor, and business licenses to source products independently. This forces reliance on the three main local distributors, who often refuse to procure niche items that don't fit their portfolio (e.g., a specific non-alcoholic champagne from Tattinger) or are unavailable on the island (e.g., golden caviar).
- **Restrictive Distributor Practices:** Current large distributors impose restrictive conditions, forcing clients to buy undesirable items (e.g., "crappy rosé") in order to access high-demand products. This "racket" conflicts with Watermark's curated, quality-focused model.
- **Unreliable Wine Stock & Poor Guest Experience:** Sean anticipates that when the property goes live, **30% of the wine list will be unavailable** due to stock issues. The digital wine list app (Vinyu) has a **three-day delay** for updates, making it impossible to manage inventory in real-time. This creates a poor experience for residents who expect seamless service.
- **Lack of Specialized Curation Services:** There is a gap in the market for high-touch, white-glove services. Sean noted that while software exists to manage residents' personal wine lockers, "there isn't anybody who can offer" a professional curation service to manage these collections for the owners, a service Watermark would like to provide.
- **Immediate Operational Overload:** Sean's most pressing pain point is the overwhelming task of opening the property and moving in 51 homeowners over the next two quarters. He has no time or "mental capacity" to engage with new projects, including a wine partnership, until the launch is complete and the property is stabilized.

### Expectations

- **Phased Engagement:** The primary expectation is to revisit the partnership proposal **after the Watermark property is open and operational**, likely after Q2 of the next year. Sean will only have the bandwidth to seriously consider the proposal once the initial launch phase is complete.
- **Reliable, One-Stop-Shop Service:** For the future, Sean expects a partner who can provide a "one-stop shop" that is completely reliable, discreet, and unobtrusive. The service must solve problems seamlessly, from sourcing exclusive SKUs (even from other suppliers) to building out private cellars, without being "fussy" or wasting the residents' time.
- **Sourcing of Exclusive Products:** The partner must be able to source unique, exclusive, and short-supply wines and spirits that are not available through mainstream channels on the island. The goal is to create an evolving, world-class culinary program that adds significant value and offers items that "others can't get."
- **White-Glove Services:** The customer is looking for a partner to provide "white-glove" services beyond simple distribution. This includes a cellar curation service for residents' private lockers and high-quality, in-person staff training (WSET or equivalent), which current distributors do not offer effectively.

### Other Information

- The residency has 51 residences and 48 owners, described as billionaires, many of whom are international.
- The staff is well-trained, with all team members qualified up to WSET Level Two in wine.
- The property has invested heavily in custom equipment, including a personalized bar cart and a chef's trolley for tableside service.
- Sean and his boss are avid Formula 1 fans, and the property plans to host F1-themed events. The consultant also has deep connections in the F1 world.
- The consultant has connections with exclusive, small-production wineries (e.g., in Burgundy and Canada) willing to allocate product to new markets.

### To-Do List

- [ ] Follow up with Sean after the initial opening phase of Watermark (after Q2 of next year) to schedule a meeting.
- [ ] Prepare a comprehensive proposal for the follow-up meeting that outlines a "White Glove," one-stop-shop service model.
- [ ] The proposal should specifically address the key pain points:
  - A technology-driven solution for the wine stock availability and Vinyu app integration issue.
  - A cellar curation and management service for residents.
  - A plan for sourcing exclusive, unique wines and spirits, leveraging existing relationships.
  - An offer for high-quality staff training.
- [ ] Offer to have the consultant's sommelier review Watermark's existing wine list to identify gaps and suggest reliably sourced alternatives as a value-add.

title: Erin & Darryl Intro Call (7 Cellars) — December 1, 2025
content:
# Erin & Darryl Intro Call (7 Cellars) — December 1, 2025

**Date:** December 1, 2025
**Duration:** 35 minutes
**Source:** [Fathom Recording](https://fathom.video/share/nz4H-wMtGvC7JCV9Jr8h1xLmVJZxGo4w)

---

## Meeting Purpose

Introductory call to align on the Cayman Islands wine import venture.

## Key Takeaways

- **Market Gap:** A clear opportunity exists in Cayman for premium, high-service wine imports, as the market is currently dominated by entry-level brands (e.g., Rombauer Chardonnay).
- **Favorable Economics:** Cayman's flat $9/liter import tax creates a level playing field, unlike NSLC's tiered system that penalizes premium wines and makes them loss leaders for importers.
- **Restaurant Pricing:** Cayman restaurants target recouping a bottle's cost with one glass, a model that makes premium wines highly profitable and is enabled by the low, flat import tax.
- **Sourcing Advantage:** Burgundy wineries are actively seeking new markets to diversify away from US tariffs, creating a direct sourcing opportunity for the new venture.

## Topics

### Cayman Market Opportunity
- Market dominated by entry-level wines like Rombauer Chardonnay (top seller)
- Proposed model: "White glove" service for high-net-worth individuals and restaurants, mirroring Bishop's Cellar's success
- Wineries actively seeking new markets to diversify away from US tariffs (currently 15% on French wine)
  - Goal: Reduce US market share to <10% of total sales
  - Result: High interest in new, smaller markets like Cayman

### Market Dynamics: NSLC vs. Cayman
- **NSLC (Nova Scotia Liquor Corporation):** Government monopoly with tiered pricing
  - Luxury Tax: Higher profit-sharing on products >$50 reduces importer margins on premium wines
  - Example (Taittinger): Landed cost $63.42 → Retail $108. Licensee discount (10%) drops margin to ~25%. Strategic discount (20%) drops to ~15% (loss leader)
  - Example (Dom Pérignon): Landed cost $243 → Retail $295. Margin 17.74% (loss leader)
- **Cayman Islands:** Flat $9/liter import tax
  - Creates level playing field — $15 bottle and $1,500 bottle incur same tax per liter
  - Makes premium wines highly profitable for restaurants and importers

### Restaurant Pricing Models
- **By-the-Glass (BTG):** Goal is to recoup bottle cost with one glass
  - Example (Gerard Bertrand Rosé): Landed cost $10.64 → Sells for ~$12-15/glass
- **By-the-Bottle:** Uses a sliding scale, not a simple 2x markup
  - Example (Taittinger): Buys for ~$75 → Sells for ~$140 (86% markup)
- Cayman: Flat import tax enables high markups on premium wines

### Logistics & Sourcing
- **Shipping:** Cayman logistics must be established
  - Potential solution: Collaborate on containers with a Puerto Rico importer to share costs
  - Risk: High summer temperatures require refrigerated containers (more expensive, harder to find)
- **Minimum Orders:**
  - High-volume wines: Large orders (e.g., 84-case pallet for South American wines)
  - Premium wines: Available in smaller quantities (e.g., 10-24 cases for Burgundy)

## Next Steps

- **Erin:**
  - Research and provide typical container shipping costs (including insurance and refrigerated options)
  - Prepare notes on the questions Darryl sent
- **Darryl:**
  - Email Erin the list of questions for the Cayman venture
- **Both:**
  - Meet in Cayman to visit restaurants and sommeliers to identify specific market gaps
  - Discuss Erin's personal goals for the venture

## Action Items

- [ ] Email Darryl landed-cost estimate for full container (shipping + insurance) — *Erin Horton*
- [ ] Email Erin follow-up questions re: Cayman wine import/logistics — *Darryl Hicks*
- [ ] Review Darryl's questions; add notes for Cayman discussions — *Erin Horton*

### Trip Planning
- Dates: Targeting early December, around Dec 2-7
- Participants: Darryl, Dwayne, Kyle, and potentially Erin (wine expert)
- Logistics:
  - Direct flights available from Toronto to Grand Cayman (Air Canada, 5 days/week)
  - Kyle mentioned CO visit and elders meeting that week; may impact accommodations
  - Kyle has apartments for rent as potential lodging for Erin

### Business Strategy
- Three-phase approach proposed:
  1. Import existing wines (simplest start)
  2. Consider RTDs (ready-to-drink beverages)
  3. Develop own vodka brand
- RTD market in Cayman less developed than North America (opportunity, but not immediate focus)
- Aim to differentiate by offering unique, high-quality wines not widely available on island
- Potential to be profitable from first container if pre-orders secured

### Meetings & Relationships
- Plan to meet with sommeliers and restaurant owners
- Strategy: Buy nice bottle, share with sommelier, discuss market trends
- Aim for 10-12 anchor accounts with purchase orders before importing
- Erin's presence crucial for credibility in wine discussions

### Licensing & Logistics
- Need to investigate liquor licensing requirements
  - Potentially need both wholesale and retail licenses
  - Kyle to research process, timing, and costs
- Explore possibility of using existing license from a contact (bartender)

### Market Insights (from Adam, industry contact)
- Incentives common for introducing new products (e.g., cash prizes for staff)
- Canadian wines could be interesting differentiator, but may require education
- Gap in market for accessible premium wines, older vintages

## Next Steps

- **Darryl:** Finalize trip dates, update business plan
- **Dwayne:** Confirm Erin's availability and arrangements
- **Kyle:** Research liquor licensing requirements and process
- **All:** Develop detailed itinerary for Cayman visit once dates confirmed
- Consider pre-selling to 10-12 anchor accounts before importing first container

## Action Items

- [ ] Send potential Cayman trip dates (early Dec, ~3rd) to group chat — *Darryl Hicks*
- [ ] Research alcohol import/retail licensing reqs, costs, timelines; explore borrowing existing license — *Kyle Klischuk*
- [ ] Update business plan w/ Adam convo insights; share w/ team for review — *Darryl Hicks*
- [ ] Confirm Erin's availability for early Dec Cayman trip; arrange same flight as Dwayne — *Dwayne Schofield*

title: 7 Cellars Partner Call — September 5, 2025
content:
# 7 Cellars Partner Call — September 5, 2025

**Date:** September 5, 2025
**Duration:** 45 minutes
**Source:** [Fathom Recording](https://fathom.video/share/zAVPzegy8dmUFbnb5_gSKCzAnVPRJXvC)

---

## Meeting Purpose

Discuss and align on initial business strategies for 7 Cellars, exploring wine and RTD (Ready-to-Drink) options for fastest path to profitability.

## Key Takeaways

- Agreement to pursue both wine and RTD options, with focus on determining fastest path to profitability
- Plan to conduct market research and explore local partnerships in Cayman for both wine and RTD production/distribution
- Potential in-person meetup in Cayman planned for late November/early December to further business discussions

## Topics

### Wine Business Strategy
- Initially thought to be fastest to profitability
- Target markets: restaurants and high-net-worth individuals building cellars
- Potential for both vintage and mass-market SKUs
- Kyle to discuss with local restaurant owners (Chad and Leif) about wine purchasing habits and interest
- Estimated margins: ~300% (e.g., $250,000 container cost, $750,000 gross revenue)

### RTD (Ready-to-Drink) Opportunity
- Fastest growing category in global liquor sales
- Potential for quicker profitability than wine due to faster production-to-sale cycle
- Explore vodka-based RTDs, possibly hard iced teas
- Investigate local co-packing options in Cayman for canning
- Dwayne to research RTD recipes and production costs with contacts in Nova Scotia

### Brand Building Strategy
- Long-term goal: Build equity in premium alcohol brand (likely vodka)
- RTD could serve as entry point for brand recognition
- Potential to layer product offerings: RTD → Vodka → Ultra-premium gift product

### Local Partnerships and Production
- Explore co-packing options with local Cayman breweries (e.g., K-Brew)
- Investigate collaborative culture among local alcohol producers in Cayman
- Kyle to discuss with local cannery about potential partnership

### Market Research
- Darryl to discuss Cayman market with 5-0, exploring both wine and RTD potential
- Kyle to meet with local restaurant owners to gauge interest and current purchasing habits

## Next Steps

- **Kyle:** Contact Chad and Leif (restaurant owners) to discuss wine purchasing and potential interest
- **Kyle:** Reach out to local Cayman cannery to explore partnership options
- **Darryl:** Set up call with 5-0 to discuss Cayman wine and RTD market
- **Dwayne:** Connect with Nova Scotia contacts for RTD recipe and production insights
- **All:** Reconvene next Friday to share findings and further develop strategy
- Consider planning in-person meetup in Cayman for late November/early December

## Action Items

- [ ] Contact neighbor (K-Brew brewmaster) re RTD co-packing possibilities, costs — *Kyle*
- [ ] Call w/ 5-0. Discuss Cayman wine market, RTD appetite. Get contacts for distribution — *Darryl Hicks*
- [ ] Contact NS RTD makers. Get recipe details, costs, samples. Ensure high quality — *Dwayne Schofield*
- [ ] Call Chad & Leif (13 restaurant owners). Discuss wine needs, pricing, interest in our plan. Set meeting if possible — *Kyle*
